titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Monday— 20. Congress. 2. Session—

Senator from Kentucky—quite shocked at the virulence of Newspaper Slanders agt. the Administration— Allen thinks I have suffered, for not turning my enemies out of office; particularly the Post-master General. Committee of both Houses of Congress, notified me that they had formed Quorums and were ready to receive any Communication from me. Answered that I should make one at 12 to-morrow— Mr Rush read me the draft of his annual report on the finances— Very pleasing—corrected the message by the revised figures of his Report— Sanford says Van Burren is not coming. He is elected Governor by a minority, in New-York. Condict spoke of Southard’s coming as Senator from New-Jersey. Fears they will make him a Non-resident; as they did Bailey. Asked if Southard could not withdraw and return to New-Jersey— I thought it unnecessary— Visit from Maryland members with others— Barney lately at Charleston S.C.— Mr Brent took Tacon’s Letters complaining of Salmon’s quarrels with Kirk’s children and servant maids— Bresson and the Duke of Montebello took leave—going to-morrow for Mexico— I rode before dinner on horseback across the Tiber round by the Navy-Yard and Eastern Branch upper bridge, returning by the Capitol— Evening visits from Mr Bailey and Coll. Little— Read to Bailey, my Letters to Bacon of Decr. 1808— Collated the two Copies of my Message for the two Houses of Congress— My Son John’s wife was taken in labour this day— Dr Worthington attends her— Mrs Nowland is her Nurse—
2. V. Tuesday— Walk to foot of College Hill.

Mr Southard brought from the Navy Department, and Major Nourse from the War Department the Documents to be sent to Congress with the Message. At Noon the Message was sent; and I had a succession of visitors Members of Congress till four in the afternoon— I then walked to the foot of College Hill— Jones came and I returned to him the Parchment Treaty and papers which Red Jacket the Oneida Indian, had left with me. Derrick brought a draft of an Instruction to J. M. Forbes— Mr Clay read me a Letter from Chief Justice Marshall, speaking very favourably of J. J. Crittenden, to fill the Office of Judge of the Supreme Court, but declining to write to me— I had offered the place to Mr Clay who declined it. I received a Letter from 13 federalists at Boston calling for names and Evidence— Also a Letter from Mr Plumer. At half past four this afternoon, my Son John’s wife was delivered of a daughter— Dr. Worthington dined with us— I had some conversation with Mr Clay and Mr Rush concerning the Letter from the federalists. Rush doubted whether I should answer it at-all—
3. V. Wednesday. Ride— College Hill and Capitol.

A continual stream of visitors, members of Congress and a few others from Breakfast till near four P.M when I took my ride of an hour and a half on horse back. Most of the members of Congress who came were friends, and they had but one topic of conversation; the loss of this day’s election. I have only to submit to it with resignation—and to ask that I, and those who are dear to me, may be sustained under it— The Sun of my political life sets in the deepest gloom— But that of my Country shines unclouded— Mr Crowell the Agent to the Creek Indians came to ask for the Argument of Walter Jones that he had left with me, claiming for the Indians the balance of a sum, stipulated by Treaty of 1821 and reserved for indemnity to Citizens of Georgia— I had given it to the Attorney General Wirt, for his opinion— The Legislature and delegation of Georgia claim the same balance for Citizens of that State— Nalls came to solicit an appointment of Lieutenant in the Marine Corps— I visited this Evening my Grand-daughter— Received this Morning a Letter from the late President Monroe— I was myself engaged on the draft of an answer to the Boston federalists—
4. V:30. Thursday.— Ride round College and Capitol—

The visits of members of Congress continue and absorbed all the morning, and unseated my tranquility of mind— This day several members of the Senate of my inveterate opponents came to pay visits of form— Mr Everett called to recommend the appointment of Mr Davis of New-York, as a Bank-Director— I invited him to dine with us, and he promised he would, but afterwards sent a note of excuse, saying he would call in the Evening which he did— Sergeant dined with us.— In the ruin of our cause he has lost his election as a Member of the House of Representatives to the next Congress— He feels severely the mortification— Lyles and Schomberg are applicants for Lieutenant’s Commissions in the Marine Corps— I spoke to Mr Reed about Coll. Dwight’s prejudices against Genl. Macomb. Long conversation in the Evening with Mr Everett on the Letter from H. G. Otis, and 12 others asking for names and Evidence. I asked his advice, whether to answer it, and how? read to him part of the draft of an answer that I had written— He took the answer with him— I continue writing upon the draft, which supersedes my paper upon Genl. Scott’s pretensions— Dorsey came to recommend a person as a Light-House keeper—named Somervill— I had already directed his appointment— Prince is a Senator from Georgia, in place of Cobb; resigned— Randolph and Sinnickson members from New-Jersey—
5. V. Friday.— Ride to Navy-Yard and Eastern Branch Bridge—

Mr Southard called to speak of the appointment a Chaplain for this South-Sea Expedition— Spoke also of his being a Candidate for Election of Senator from New-Jersey in the place of Dickerson— Wishes not to stand in the way of Frelinghuysen— I read to him the draft of my answer to Otis and others— But I shall take further time for consideration before sending it— Sloane was here, with a man from Louisiana who wanted to see the house— Sloane is another victim to the overwhelming ruin of this Administration— He has lost his Election to the next Congress. William Lee has just returned from New-York— Says he met Otis there who was very abusive upon me; and told him that I should meet with a bad reception upon my return home next Spring.— I hear from other quarters that some of the principal old federalists have determined to break off all personal intercourse with me; so that I shall go into retirement with I know not how many bitter controversies upon my hands—Hinckley is a Portrait Painter from Rhode-Island who brought Letters of introduction from Mr Knight the Senator and another, and applied to me to sit to him for my picture. Mr Scott came to apply for an appointment— A Mr Barker of South-Carolina, recently from Vera-Cruz and Mexico came to make a visit of curiosity; introducing himself— He spoke of the violent secret proceedings of the South-Carolina Delegation in this City last Spring—especially of Hayne and Hamilton— He said Hamilton was unwell—having had an Hemorrage of the Lungs— With the exception of the interruptions by visitors and my ride, all the leisure of this day was absorbed in writing—chiefly to W. Plumer, of Epping, New Hampshire—
6. V. Saturday.— Walk round Capitol Square—

Members of Congress visitors; more than half of those that came this day; implacable political enemies; but I must receive all alike— With Mr Marks the Senator from Pennsylvania came a Clergyman, from appearance a German, who made of me some enquiries concerning the Genevan French Translation of the Bible— He spoke of Mr Campbell’s preaching to-morrow at the second Presbyterian Church to-morrow, and expressed some curiosity to hear him. I invited Mr Marks and him to take Seats in my pew— Mr Smith the Senator from South-Carolina spoke of the newspaper controversy between Mr Mitchel and Genl. Hayne, with others of that delegation, and said he thought Mitchell had the best of it. Coll. Trumbull read to me his proposed Report to the House of Representatives, of the measures taken by him for the preservation of his paintings. Mr Thomas the Senator from Illinois told me he was satisfied with the course he had taken in supporting the present Administration— He said I had fewer personal enemies than any other public man he knew. How mistaken! Mr Everett spent the Evening with me; and returned me the federal Letter, I had lent him— I desired him to invite Mrs Everett to come with him and dine with us to-morrow. He asked me to postpone for ten or twelve days answering the Letter.
7. VI:30. Sunday— Rain
Heard Campbell at 2d. Presbyterian Church— Hebrews 13–14
Hawley at St. John’s— Second Sunday in Advent— Isaiah 44.–7 to end.
Mr and Mrs Everett dined with us.

I attended morning Service at the Presbyterian Church; where Mr Campbell, their recently elected Minister preached from Hebrews 13.14. “For here have we no continuing City, but we seek one to come.”— The doctrine that the Christian’s life must be a life of trials and of troubles, and of toils was well deduced from this text. Mr Campbell has much improved since I last heard him, and is now eloquent— Mr Marks and his clerical friend were there— Mr Campbell gave notice that his Evening services would in future be at half-past six.

Mr Hawley’s afternoon service was short—omitting the reading of the Psalms and of the Lesson from the Old Testament— His discourse was an exposition of the 44th. chapter of Isaiah from verse 7 to the end— The ironical, indignant and picturesque description of the manufacture of wooden gods— The day was foul and the attendance at Church very thin— Mr and Mrs Everett dined with us, and he afterwards passed an hour with me in my chamber— He says that Mr Gorham the member of the House from Boston, is among the persons offended by the publication in the Intelligencer and Journal of 21. October last, authorised by me— He says too that the persons to whom H. G. Otis in his Letter of 15. October to T. Dwight alludes as having sacrificed him to appease the Angry Gods of the old Democracy, and of whom he speaks as the real fathers of the Hartford Convention were the Connecticut River federalists.— I was occupied in answering a Letter from my Son Charles who has sent me the Jackson Republican of 29. October, containing Lyman’s libel upon Webster, and several other old federalists; for which Lyman has been indicted by the presentment of Webster— My troubles thicken upon me— What will be the end of this controversy is known only to the great disposer of all Events— To me is only left to implore that my strength may be proportioned to the trials before me—
8. V. Monday.— Ride to Navy Yard and Eastern Branch—

The current of visitors members of Congress has subsided— But a few of them occasionally fall in and bring with them their friends or acquaintance to introduce them— Visitors still occupy my time from ten in the morning till dinner, leaving me scarcely an interval of one or two hours for my ride or my walk— My hours of writing must be, from rising till breakfast, and the Evening after eight— Major Nourse came for papers to be copied, and to bring back part of my manuscript upon Genl. Scott’s claims. Mr Whittlesey of Ohio, was overset in a Stage before reaching the City, and much hurt. Some days confined to his chamber, and now barely convalescent— He spoke of the Petitions of Robert Eaton to be released from a judgment against him— The papers are at the Treasury or War Department— Mr Johns introduced Mr Comegys, who brings the Electoral votes of Delaware to the seat of Government— Mr Brent has been making a fruitless search at the Department of State, for the original papers of John Henry— Linsey is a Baltimore Manufacturer who brought me a Letter from L. Tiernan. Genl. Macomb came with his brother in Law Balch and his Son, who now resides at Frederick, in Maryland, but whom I saw at Leesburg in 1825. Mr Frye made enquiries concerning the debt of the Columbian College and the 500 dollars of it belonging to Mr T. B. Johnson, but standing in my name— He thinks of accepting a compromise which they are making with some of the small Creditors— Major Hamilton came to report himself again as a Petitioner for place— Coll. Jones to introduce his brother who wishes to go as Chaplain upon the South-Sea Expedition— Blunt is just from New-York— I sent to the Senate Messages N. 1. 2. 3. and to the House of Representatives Messages N. 1. 2— Mr and Mrs Frye, and their Son Tom dined with us.
9. V. Tuesday.— Ride— College and Capitol—

Mr Storrs introduced a young man by the name of Van Rensselaer from Utica—not of the Patroon’s family. Blunt came to ask for appointment as Charge d’Affaires in Denmark, in the place of Henry Wheaton said to be deceased— He offered to procure recommendations, which I advised him to do— Coll. Thomas brought papers relating to a claim upon which he wishes for my decision— He also told me of sayings, of Coll. Gardiner and Simpson of the Post Office, from which he infers that the Post-master General, M’lean has cast off his allegiance to Mr Calhoun, and thinks himself a suitable candidate for the Presidency— But Gardner tells him that M’lean is now to be Secretary of the Treasury— Judge Wright is the Engineer— Employed upon the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— Mr Handy introduced Dr Jones— He says Mr Campbell has accepted the pastoral charge of the 2d. Presbyterian Church for a few Months; and that a number of Pews have been taken since he came— But that 47. of 120 communicants went off and have formed a new Church and called Mr Danforth who has accepted— Mr Bailey spent the Evening with me— He enquired if I would accept a Seat in the Senate, from Massachusetts if it should be offered me— I answered that the first objection would be that I would on no consideration displace any other man— He said he believed Mr Silsbee was very averse to coming again to the Senate, and would be glad to decline, if I would accept— I said there were other objections, my intention being to go into the deepest retirement, and withdraw from all connection with public Affairs— He said Dr Condict of New-Jersey, had expressed to him the hope that I should not thus withdraw— I shewed Mr Bailey, the Letter from the 13 Federalists; and read to him the draft of my answer— Also my Letter of 16. August 1809 to W. Plumer, and his recent Letter to me received by the same Mail with that of the 13. I sent to the Senate Message N. 4. and signed 25 Blank Mediterranean Passports—
10. V. Wednesday Ride, College and Capitol Hills.

Mr White of Florida came to enquire concerning the printing of his compilation of Spanish Florida Land Laws— The three members of the House from Kentucky came with Mr Trimble one of the Judges of the Arkansas Territory— They wished me to send in the renominations forthwith as Trimble’s Commission is about to expire—and there is a capital trial pending to be brought on at this Session of the Court in January— Buckner wished me to postpone the nomination of a Judge of the Supreme Court for a few days to receive recommendations of George Robertson— Pearce came to recommend a young man of R— Island named Calhoun for an appointment of Purser in the Navy— Coll. Thomas brought me some additional papers concerning his claims— Mrs Darby to dispose of some Geographical books, published by her husband— Thomas says William King of Maine is here intriguing with the Senators, to get Preble appointed Minister to the Netherlands and Hughes superseded. Blunt called to say that the rumour of the decease of Henry Wheaton, Charge d’Affaires in Denmark was a mistake of him for his brother— The methodists came for a contribution to build a Church in Georgetown— Mr Coxe is a Presbyterian Clergyman with whom I travelled from New-York to Providence in a Steamboat in 1825— Lee came to renew his solicitation for the appointment of his Son as a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps— Barbour spoke of Anti-Tariff Resolutions before the South-Carolina Legislature— As I was riding out I met in the Yard Mr Clay, who mentioned the nominations to be made to the Senate— C. C. Woodward called in the Evening to ask Letters of recommendation from me to the Governor of the State of Mississippi which I declined giving.
11. IV:30. Thursday— Walk round Capitol Square—

Linsey came to borrow money Leffler a member of the House from Virginia, to introduce a Dr Jones of his District— Miner to apologize for having written to me yesterday to recommend the appointment of Edward Ingersoll as Charge d’Affaires in Denmark; which he said he had done at Ingersoll’s request— Ingersoll very recently declined the appointment of Charge d’Affaires in Peru— Miner asked me if I had determined definitively to withdraw from all public Service, after the expiration of my present term— I told him that my intention was absolute and total retirement— But my principle would be what it had been through life— I should seek no public employment in any form, directly or indirectly— It was not for me to foresee whether my Services would ever be desired by my fellow Citizens again— If they should call for them, while I have life and health, I shall not hold myself at Liberty to decline repairing to any Station which they may assign to me; except for reasonable cause— But I desired him to receive this in Confidence, as a candid answer to his questions for I wish not even to give a hint to the public that I am yet eligible to their Service— Mr Rush had papers relating to an exaction of duties on certain Articles of household furniture brought back by Alexis Eustaphieve, Russian Consul-General, now at New-York; heretofore Consul at Boston— I advised that they should all be admitted duty free, not by any privilege as Consul, but as part of his baggage— Mr Tyler, Senator from Virginia, told me that Governor Barbour had written to his Overseer to lay down all his lands in wheat; in consequence of which all his neighbours had done the same— Governor Kent’s term of Office is expiring: and he is desponding. He has gone through his Constitutional three years and is no longer eligible— Captain Beard is recommended by the Secretary of War as Indian Agent in Florida, in place of H. Montgomery to be removed— I sent to the Senate Messages N. 5. and 6— Nominations.
12. IV:15. Friday Ride round College and Capitol Hills

Mr Graham came with a Letter from W. Hendricks Senator from Indiana; about a statement in the Telegraph, that Indian reservations of Lands were allowed to be located within the Canal Grant to the State of Indiana. Mr Graham proposed to write to the Register of the Land Office to allow no entries within five Sections of the river, where the Canal may run, for it is itself not yet located— To this I agreed— Mr Southard introduced Mr Moore, the young man, who brought the electoral votes from New-Jersey— Persico came—just returned from a Northern Tour, as far as Boston— He is going to Italy, but wishes to be employed for further Sculpture at the Capitol. His execution of my design at the Tympanum of the Pediment was finished just before the meeting of Congress, and is much approved. Mr Hinckley the Portrait painter came and repeated the request that I would sit to him for my picture— I promised I would as soon as I could find leisure— Coll. Trumbull brought his bill for compensation for his work under a Resolution of the House of Representatives, for the preservation of his pictures— Mr Elgar disputes his Bill (about 1100 dollars, which Elgar proposes reducing to 750) I told the Coll. that if Elgar would take my opinion, I would advise him to allow the whole bill— Mr Clay was here, and spoke of the nomination of a judge of the Supreme Court— Also of attempts of W. King of Maine to get Mr Preble appointed Minister to the Netherlands, to the exclusion of C. Hughes— I nominated Hughes yesterday.— We had company to dine—Bartlett, Bryan, Butman, Condict, Drayton, Frye and Mrs Gallatin and Son, Gorham, Gurley Ingersoll R. J. and Mrs. Johns, Johnson R. M. Labat, Little, Mallary, Marable, Owen and Mrs. Preble, Randolph J. F. Sanford, and Mrs. Sergeant, Shaler, Silsbee, Smith Saml. Stevenson, Andrew and Mrs. Taylor J. W. Van Rensselaer Stephen and Verplanck. 40 at table—
13. V:15. Saturday. Ride round College and Capitol Hills

Mr Elgar called and I gave him my opinion that the whole bill of Coll. Trumbull should be allowed— Mr White came to speak of the appointment of keeper of the public Archives for East Florida— Joseph S. Sanchéz to be appointed. He spoke also concerning the removal of G. Humphreys, at which I demurred— Mr Silsbee called and said Mr Bailey had spoken to him about his declining to be a candidate for re-election to the Senate. He said he was very averse to remaining in the Senate; but he had consented to be a candidate for re-election; and could not well withdraw—though he should be very glad to resign in a year or two. I entreated him never to think of resigning on my account, and assured him I would not come into the public service again by displacing any of my friends— Wilde and Haynes, members of the House from Georgia, spoke of the Georgia claims to more Indian indemnities. I told them the Attorney General had given his opinion in which I concurred that I had no power to act in the case. Commodore Tingey came to take leave of me— Pearce to bespeak again the pursership for Calhoun— Genl. Porter with another pamphlet of Genl Scott’s— I agreed not to remove G. Humphreys unheard, and spoke to Genl. Porter in favour of R. H. Lee for a Clerkship— Danforth and Stansbury came for a contribution to the erection of a new Presbyterian Church; and for an order for a guard of the Marine Corps to attend while Danforth may preach to the prisoners in gaol— Blunt dined with us— He says T. Pickering is writing a controversial life of A. Hamilton— He says also that R. Walsh told him four years ago, that Chief Justice Parsons told him travelling from Boston to Northampton in 1822. We need not disguise it—we do mean a separation from the Union, and to shake off the negro States— Mr Everett spent the Evening with me, and made several enquiries of me—particularly as to the prospects of Mr Clay and Mr Van Buren— Also as to my attendance on the 4th of March next.
14. V:15. Sunday.
Heard Mr Hawley at St. John’s. 3d. Sunday in Advent—from Titus 2.13.

Mr Bigelow’s discourse—Luke 1.78 [“]Through the tender mercy of our God; whereby the day-spring from on high hath visited us, 79. To give light to them that sit in darkness, and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet in the way of Peace.” It was by far the best I ever heard from him. On the excellence of Christianity as a perfect system of morals, and its influence on the human character— After the Sermon Mrs Knight sung “Angels ever bright and fair,” with accompaniment of the organ, and lap’d me in Elysium— Walking home I was overtaken by Mr Everett— I asked him if he was the writer of three Articles in the National Intelligencer upon the Talk of the Winnebago Indians with me the 29th. of last Month— He was not— I suppose it was Miner. The Articles, especially the last, published yesterday, are very well written, and give an exact account of the talk— Sergeant called upon me after the morning service— I spoke to him of the Letter I have received from the 13 federalists—we were interrupted by Ringgold and Lee— Ringgold came Friday Morning from Mr Monroe’s at Oakhill; and brought me a very kind message from him, and from the family; and a promise that he would shortly write to me in reply to my two last Letters. I heard Mr Hawley from Titus 2:13. “Looking for that blessed hope”— The Sermon contained a description somewhat circumstantial, of Heaven— C. Dorsey and J Sergeant were at Church, and Sergeant on coming out told me that he would call upon me to-morrow, and talk of the federal Letter— He said he had heard much of the subject, which had produced a very extensive and unpleasant effect— Evening at home, and I finished the draft of my observations upon General Scott’s claim to command General Macomb— But his last pamphlet of 60 pages will require perhaps a week more of occupation upon this subject— I propose to have my observations published in a pamphlet, and informally laid upon the table, in both Houses of Congress, for the use of the members— There are several precedents for this course— T. J. Hellen came here yesterday and returned to the College this afternoon—
15. V: Monday.— Ride round College and Capitol—

Mr Silsbee introduced the two brothers Fitch, and Captain Coffin, who is an applicant for the appointment of Collector at Newbury-Port— General Porter came to enquire for the Agreement of U.S. Commissioners Cass and Menard with the Winebagos and other Indians concerning the temporary occupation of their Mining Lands. It was mislaid— Mr Shaler brought me a Letter to him from a friend in Boston; the signature was taken off—advising him to apply for the appointment of Postmaster at Boston—supposing that there would be shortly a new appointment. I told Shaler I had no expectation that there would be; and if there should, it would be difficult to go out of the City for an Officer— Mr Seymour came with a Letter from Heman Allen, soliciting the appointment of Minister to Mexico, or any other Mission abroad; on account of Mrs Allen’s delicate health— Mr Rush asked advice, concerning a lawyer’s Bill of R. S. Coxe, employed as assistant Counsel in the Supreme Court, by the Attorney General— He asks 1000 dollars for 3 arguments— We agreed that 750 would be liberal allowance. I gave Mr Rush my Letter to 13. for examination— Mr Clay urged the immediate nomination of J. J. Crittenden as Judge of the U.S. Supreme Court in the place of Robert Trimble deceased— Mr Clay spoke also of a draught of a Note to Mr Vaughan, complaining of a new attempt to impress two American Seamen at Campeche—and proposed to instruct Mr Barbour about it, to which I agreed— Coll. Thomas came about his claim, the papers relating to which I had not examined— He said the Jackson central Committee here, were arranging all the appointments to replace the persons to be dismissed—and Morfit one of them told him, that he, Morfit was to have a place, pretty high— Mr Southard, brought the records—lists of Purser and Midshipmen candidates; for a selection to be made—four or five out of 150. We went over the names, and selected about ten from which the choice is to be made— J. Sergeant and Blunt were successively here in the Evening. I read to Sergeant my answer to the 13. Sent Messages to S.U.S. N. 7. Additional Article to Hanseatic Treaty—and to H.R.U.S. N. 3. fugitive Slaves—
16. VII. Tuesday.— Walk to the College— Exhibition

Mrs Beale is of Prince George’s County Maryland— She came with her daughter to solicit a Midshipman’s warrant for one of her Sons named Bowie— Mr Phillebrown, a Clerk in the Navy Department came and introduced his father an old revolutionary Officer, recently one of the Electors of President and Vice-President in the State of Maine, and now bearer of the electoral votes to this place— Mr Seymour came and introduced judge Strong of Vermont— Captain Coffin, brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr Webster, for the Appointment of Collector at Newbury-Port. I walked to the College, and attended the exhibition of the Junior Class— There were six performers; all English Orations—one of them by Thomas J. Hellen— At intervals between two and two of the performances there were interludes of instrumental Music. The whole was preceded by a prayer by the President Mr Chapin. Dr Semple, President of the Board of Trustees was present, and invited me after the ceremonies were over to dine with them, which I declined. The exhibition room, small and underground was well filled with company— Chiefly Ladies— The performances were very creditable— This Institution is ruined with debt— Has been once broken up for more than a year. And though lately resumed will probably again fall through— I walked home; and after I returned Professor Williston of Captain Partridge’s Academy came to enquire if recommendations would yet be received for the appointment of Collector at Middletown, Connecticut—where Henry Wolcott was temporarily appointed last Summer— I answered him shortly No Sir—and added the practice is universally otherwise— He withdrew— Sent Message to the Senate N. 8. the Lead Mine Agreement with the Winebagoes and other Indian tribes— Vacation at the College.
17. V. Wednesday— Bridge-ride. 1st. Drawing-room—

Ober is a mendicant Clergyman; of whom there are numbers here— Mr Daniel Brent came for despatches of S. Larned, and of J. R. Poinsett— Mr Brent of Louisiana called to recommend H. H. Gurley as District Judge for that district in place of T. H. Robertson, who died some weeks since. Mr Mitchell, a member of the House of Representatives from South-Carolina called to visit me— I spoke to him of the controversy in which he has been engaged the last Autumn—with the rest of the South-Carolina Delegation at the last Session of Congress, there having been meetings at Mr Hayne’s lodgings of a violent character as threatening disunion— Mitchell has all the delegation against him, excepting W. Smith the Senator—but his Testimony overbalances all theirs. Mr Rush returned me my Answer to the 13. approving its purport as does Mr Southard— But Rush yet hesitates a little on the question whether I ought to answer it at-all, while I am in Office— Mr Rush spoke of the Seizure of the Revenue Cutter, by the Collector at Key West, for a breach of the Revenue— An extraordinary and unprecedented procedure. He had also a Letter from C. J. Ingersoll at Philadelphia, recommending his Cousin Willcox, formerly Consul at Canton in China, for a Director of Bank U.S.— Mr Thomas the Senator from Illinois came at the request of a part of the Delegation from the State of Ohio, to recommend a Mr Ewing of that State to be a judge of the U.S. Supreme Court in the place of R. Trimble. But I had already determined to nominate J. J. Crittenden of Kentucky— Mr Southard brought the papers relating to a contract for purchasing Stone, for the Delaware River Breakwater— He has been very ill again, and was this day compelled to go away leaving the papers with me— Cresson is a Quaker— He came now to ask me to write a few lines in his Album, which I promised to do— Mr Pearce of Rhode-Island came again to solicit an appointment of Purser in the Navy to a young man named Cahoon— Massias is a Paymaster stationed at Charleston S.C. whose term of service has expired— To be renominated— First drawing-room this Evening— There was dancing in the East-room— T. J. Hellen is with us— I sent Message to S.U.S. N. 9— Nominations—
18. V:15 Thursday. Ride— College and Capitol—

General Hinds is a new Member of the House of Representatives in the place of Haile, who failing of a Re-election to the next Congress, resigned his Seat for the remaining term of this— Labat is a French man traveling in this Country who brought Letters of introduction from Madame Hyde de Neuville to Mrs Adams— Mr Bell Senator from New-Hampshire made some enquiries respecting some recent nominations which have been referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations of which he is a member. Tazewell is the Chairman, and Mr Bell expects there will be opposition to the appointments— C. Hughes now Chargé d’Affaires to the Netherlands is nominated Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to the same Court— Tazewell thinks that this would give Hughes two characters, that of Envoy Extraordinary being limited to the execution of some special mission— I told Mr Bell that the two characters were in the practice of European Diplomacy always united together, and had generally been so in ours since the Mediation Mission to Russia— He asked whether it was proposed to give Mr Hughes a full outfit— I told him it was—but that the appropriation must depend upon the Will of Congress— He enquired respecting the transfer of J. A. Smith as Secretary of Legation from Madrid to Paris, and of Samuel Larned as Charge d’Affaires from Chili to Peru, for which I gave him the reasons— Mr Gurley and W. L. Brent called to recommend Dr Sibley for an Indian Agency; and Brent to recommend Gurley for U.S. District Judge in Louisiana— Mr Hayne Senator from S.C. for a visit— Mr Southard took the papers relating to the Break water Stone contract which we disapprove— The error is of C. C. Biddle and Strickland. Daniel Brent brought a Record Book of the War Department of 1793— J. Sergeant spent the Evening with me, and had much conversation with me; respecting my Letter to the 13.— I took my ten Mile ride this day before dinner but suffered severely with the cold— Thomas J. Hellen is with us during the vacation— John dined at Baron Krudener’s—it being St. Nicholas—the Emperor’s name day.
19. V. Friday.— Short walk— Company to dine—

Mr Joseph C. Hart belongs to New-York. He is desirous of going with the expedition to the Southern Ocean as its Journalist and he brought two Letters of recommendation—one from Dr Mitchill— He said he had brought me one sometime since from Charles King— I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Labat told me he had been travelling several months in various parts of this Country and he mentioned what he had heard said of me— The testimonial was flattering but confined to the smaller number— Mr Sloane of Ohio introduced his friend Wooster— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me a Resolution of the Senate, confirming the appointment of J. A. Smith as Secretary of the Legation at Paris, and several Consuls— Mr Clay and Mr Rush were here together— Mr Clay spoke of Mr Tazewell’s scruples about the title of Envoy Extraordinary to Hughes; and his questions whether a full outfit is to be allowed him— I gave Mr Clay my Letter to the 13— Mr Rush asked me for the papers, relating to the seizure of the Revenue Cutter, by the Collector at Key-West— Also of C. J. Ingersoll’s proposal to come here to argue before the Supreme Court the Thompson Tea case— We agreed not to let him come— He would be sure to lose the cause; as he has invariably done at Philadelphia— Mr Clarke the Treasurer came to recommend some person for an appointment— Blunt called to make a friendly visit— Mr Frye with a young man named Beall, to solicit for the latter a Clerkship in the pay Department of the War Office vacated by the Death last Evening of Mr Andrew Ramsay— Mr Dorsey came to ask the same thing for his Son in Law— Richard Henry Lee has asked me for it, and I am anxiously desirous that it should be conferred upon him— Coll. Thomas came for his papers, but I had not done with them— Short walk before dinner— Cold. Company to dine—Baldwin, Bates, Bell Blake, Brugiere Miss, Carter, Chambers of Ky Crowninshield Dickinson—J. D. and Mrs Dorsey, Fillebrown, Hoffman, Knight Mrs Lea, Long, Miner, Newton, Seymour—H. and Mrs. Shepperd, Sinnickson, Sloane, Stewart, Teisseire, Mr and Mrs Thomas, J. B. Tyler White Joseph M. and Mrs Wingate Joseph F and Mrs.— Six of us— Mrs Smith confined, unwell—
20. V. Saturday. Ride Navy-Yard and Eastern Branch Bridge—

list.item: 21. Visitors from before Breakfast till 4. P.M.

div.p: Coll. Thomas came again about his papers— I agreed to see his Counsel Mr Coxe, Monday Morning at ten— Mr Allen, Member from Massachusetts introduced Mr Goodenow a merchant from Montreal—emigrant from Boston. Mr Gurley came with Mr Elpont who called himself a Creole of Louisiana— Mr Adams is an Applicant for Office whom I referred to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Lumpkin, Member from Georgia told me his wife was a native of Massachusetts—he introduced Mr Gordon, a Georgian— Mr Swann brought me a friendly Letter from Mr Monroe. Came from Oakhill yesterday morning. Coll. Washington came to recommend Mr Beall for the vacant Clerkship in the Paymaster General’s Office— Mr Haynes member from Georgia, for the papers transmitted with the Letter from the Georgia delegation at the close of the last Session of Congress— One of the papers was missing; and Mr Haynes will call again on Monday— Mr Wright of Ohio, introduced Mr Muhlenberg the new Member from that State in the place of Judge Creighton— General Brady and Coll. Worth came together— Mr Pearce to enquire again if Mr Cahoon had obtained the appointment of Purser. Lewis Williams member from North-Carolina came as a friendly visitor— Mr Bailey also— Owen of Alabama to enquire if I had remitted a penalty in the case of a man named Robertson of Mobile— I said I had not, and upon the Evidence could not— He concurred with me in opinion. General Porter brought and left with me a Letter to be sent from him to General Scott—which he left with me for consideration— I renewed the recommendation of R. H. Lee, as a Clerk in the paymaster General’s Office; and of Dr Sibley for the Caddo Indian Agency. Mr Clay brought back my Letter to the 13. upon which he made some remarks— I rode before dinner to the Navy-Yard and Eastern Branch Bridge, and passed the Evening in writing; chiefly observations upon General Scott’s claims of command—
21. V:30. Sunday.
At St. John’s—4th. Sunday in Advent—

Heard Bishop Onderdonk James 5.16. “The effectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much.” a Sensible ingenious and not ineloquent discourse upon prayer— The Bishop’s voice is clear and strong— His delivery grave solemn and unaffected—with quite sufficient action for a written Sermon. His Style plain, with little but suitable ornament—the divisions of his subject only two—the efficacy of prayer and the qualities which render it efficacious— There was no analysis of the text—no explanation of the seemingly redundant word effectual, no comment upon the fervour, of Spirit, and righteousness of life required to render prayer availing— The arguments were in generalities, and the most striking thought that prayer although its immediate object may be denied, may still avail much to him who prays— In the afternoon there were two Strangers with Mr Hawley; one of whom read the whole evening service, and the other preached from Amos 4.12. “Prepare to meet thy God.” The coldness of the discourse, in matter and manner was in strong contrast to the awful solemnity of the text— Mr Hoffman of Baltimore; and Judge Cranch, with our Classmate Dr Fiske of Worcester called on me after the morning service— Dr Fiske brings the electoral votes of Massachusetts, and said he wished he had come on a more profitable errand— Elliot Cresson came and took back his Album in which I had promised to write a few lines but had not found time for doing it— He said he expected to be here again in about a month, and would then send it to me again— Mr Sergeant dined and spent the Evening with us; and Mr Blunt came in after dinner. I received a Letter from my Son Charles concerning the Letter from the 13 to me— Josiah Quincy has failed after a second trial, of being re-elected Mayor of Boston, and withdraws— And the Jury upon the trial of T. Lyman, for a libel upon D. Webster, could not agree—10. and 11. for conviction—2 and 1 for acquittal.
22. V. Monday— Walk College and Kalorama.

Mr Coxe came as Counsel for Coll. Thomas upon his claims on the Treasury, and gave me some further explanations concerning them— I spoke to him also upon those of William Tharp, and the strong suspicion of forgery resting upon his papers— Major Nourse, for whom I sent, told me there were no War Office Records of General R. Butler’s Commissions in 1791. Mr Thomas, Senator from Illinois introduced Captain Dean of the Army and Mr Deacon— General Porter was here twice—first I gave him a draft of a Letter to General Scott, instead of that which he had prepared— The second time he came to ask me to reconsider my draft which he thought too severe— I agreed to give it up, and he is to prepare and submit to me a third draft tomorrow— Scott is here and General Porter brought the second time he came his Letter announcing his arrival; by which he considers himself as quasi in Arrest— Mr Rush had a Letter from Mr Wirt at Baltimore, mentioning judge Duval’s wish that he might be employed to assist Mr Williams, the District Attorney in a cause before the Circuit Court. U.S. vs the Bank of Somerset— We concluded to employ him with a fee of 500 dollars— Coll. Jones brought me a volume of Records containing copies of all the Commissions issued to army Officers during the present Administration— No such copies have been hitherto kept— The practice is introduced at my request. Mr Kerr and General Van Rensselaer came to solicit the vacant appointment of Clerk in the Paymaster General’s Office for Richard B. Dorsey. William Lee came to enquire if the appointment of Lieutenant in the Marine Corps which he solicits for his Son has been made— It has not—Mr Southard the Secretary of the Navy being ill, and unable to transact business— S. A. Elliot brought me two Copies of his Congressional Directory for the present Session, and of his pocket Almanack for 1829. He said his brother was now in Paris, and offered any services that he could render me there. Blunt was here in the Evening— Going for New-York to-morrow. I sent Message N. 4. to the House of Representatives: with two Reports from the Secy of War—Lead Mine Leases and Choctaw Indians.
23. V:15. Tuesday— Walk round Capitol Square

Mr Hunt a member of the House of Representatives from Vermont introduced Mr Phelps one of the Electors at the late Presidential Election there and the Messenger who brings the electoral votes— Mr Gurley introduced Mr Jehiel Brooks who solicits the appointment of Agent to the Caddo Indians on Red River. The same appointment for which Dr Sibley is likewise an applicant— Mr Clay was here, and spoke of the agency of Mr Gallatin and Mr Preble, on the North-eastern boundary question: and the amount of compensation to be allowed them— Mr Clay thought it would be best not to send in an estimate for a specific appropriation; but to make them the allowance, and pay it from the contingent expenses of foreign intercourse— I inclined to sending an estimate and asking a specific appropriation— The allowance to be 4500 dollars each, and to Mr. Preble 7000 dollars if he goes to Europe— Mr Clay has a despatch and a private Letter, from Governor Barbour in London— In the latter he says that our Tariff is as unpopular in England as in South-Carolina—and thinks it probable that Mr Huskisson will bring forward some project of retaliation, at the next Session of Parliament— Mr Silsbee brought and shewed me a Letter, recommending Mr Currier for the Office of Collector at Newbury-Port— General Porter brought the draft of his Letter to General Scott, prepared upon his own former draft and mine— I approved it as he now had it. He also brought me the proceedings of a Court-martial at West-Point, sentencing a Cadet named Dargan to be shot to death for raising a weapon against his Officer— He said he thought I should disapprove the Sentence— Mr D. Brent brought me a second Volume of War Department Reports which explained to me the Major General’s Commission of Richard Butler in 1791— Mr Evans of Baltimore dined with us—and Mr and Mrs Everett were here in the Evening. I gave him to peruse, my Answer to the Letter of the 13. He spoke of Dr Floyd’s Bill which is again before the House of Representatives for erecting the Territory of Oregon at the Mouth of Columbia River—
24. VI. Wednesday— Walk to College Hill—

Mr Graham called to ask if I had made a decision upon a claim of his for compensation for extra-services— I said I had not; but that the impression upon my mind had been unfavourable to it—as I thought he had expressly waved it— He insisted that he had not— Urged that allowances had always been made for extra services; and that Congress had last year or the year before passed an Act making such an allowance to P. Hagner the third Auditor— In his own case the power was discretionary in the President. I promised to re-examine his papers, and reconsider the claim— Mr Cutts the second Comptroller called and took the papers relating to Coll. Thomas’s claims— Mr Vance introduced Mr Gillespie. Mr Woods—member of the House, mentioned that he had recommended Mr Brooks for the Caddo Indian Agency, but that he would prefer Dr Sibley. Mr Pearce introduced Mr Cross bearer of the electoral votes from Rhode-Island— Mr Newton introduced Mr King of Norfolk—and spoke of Mr Madison’s two Letters on the constitutionality of the Tariff—one published yesterday and the other to come tomorrow in the National Intelligencer— Mr Owen introduced Mr Hunt of Mobile— Dr Reynolds Mr Wilson and Mr Long who are going on the expedition to the South-Sea— Major Waldron is the bearer of the New-Hampshire electoral votes— Mr Neale brought a petition numerously signed from Alexandria for the remission of a fine, to Wyllis Anderson, convicted of Manslaughter— Judges Cranch and Thruston, and the District Attorney Swan recommend it— Anderson has suffered . . . years imprisonment— I remitted the fine— Mr Bryan introduced Mr Iredell the new Senator from North-Carolina, in the place of Nathaniel Macon— Mr Lee mentioned his Memoirs of the life of Arthur Lee, which are now in the press at Boston, and of a remarkable Letter from Dr Franklin respecting Silas Deane— Mr Bouligny the Senator from Louisiana was here—just arrived from Louisiana— My horse being lame I am obliged to return to my old exercise of walking—
25. IV:30— Thursday— Christmas—

Heard Mr Bigelow at the Unitarian Church from John 1.46. “And Nathanael said unto him, can there any good thing come out of Nazareth? Philip saith unto him, Come and see.” The Sermon was upon the influence of Christianity upon the world— The subject was nearly the same as that which he preached the Sunday before last, and very good—except that it closed with a very violent denunciation of the Roman Catholic and of the Calvinistic doctrines— On Christmas day of all others, Christians of every denomination should forget all their animosities and dissensions, and adhere to the Law of Love— After the morning service, I had as visitors Mr Wirt, the Attorney General, Mr Calhoun, Vice-President and Mr Rush— Mr Wirt comes to keep Christmas at home from Baltimore where he is attending Court— I gave him the Letter of the 13 to read: and told him I should ask his advice upon the answer I have prepared to it; which is now in the hands of Mr Everett— I also read to him my Letter to W. Plumer, of 16. August 1809; which he advised me to publish. Mr Calhoun the Vice-President’s visit was one of form, and Mr Rush’s one of friendship— Calhoun has just arrived from Carolina— With Mrs Adams, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, my Son John, T. J. Hellen, and Abigail S. Adams, I dined at Mr Frye’s— Mr Sanford the Senator from New-York, Mr and Mrs Barrell, and Johnson Hellen were there— My Son’s wife is not yet sufficiently recovered from her lying in, to leave her chamber— We spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s— I am so much habituated to home, that it is irksome to me to pass a single evening, or to dine abroad— And I earnestly hope that this disposition may remain after my retirement from the public service— I was engaged all the leisure time of this day, in reading over the Observations upon the claim of General Scott to command Generals Macomb and Gaines—the second draft of which is now finished; forming a manuscript of 120 pages— It would require a third writing over, for which I shall not have the time— Its great fault now is, its length—and the numerous repetitions contained in it— There is also perilous matter for myself— But I have written it under a deep sense of duty—
26. V. Friday— Walk to College Hill— Dinner

Persico called to speak of a Resolution offered by Mr Buchanan, to the House of Representatives, to authorise him to execute other works of Sculpture, at the Capitol— He wished that the Subjects might be left to the selection of the President— Supposing that if they should attempt to fix upon the Subjects by Congress, for 300 members there would be 300 Opinions— He proposed that there should be at the two sides of the front Stairs two emblematical groups of War and Peace— Mr Vinton came and introduced Judge Burnett, the new Senator from Ohio elected to supply the place of General Harrison— Mr Fendall thanked me in the name of R. H. Lee, to whom the Secretary of War had mentioned my wish that he should receive the vacant clerkship in the Paymaster General’s Office— Dr. Watkins introduced Mr Etting lately from Buenos-Ayres, and Mr Sanders from Lima— T. M. Taylor brought a Letter from John W Taylor and is an applicant for the appointment of a Purser in the Navy— A Nephew of Lieutt. Governor T. L. Winthrop— Mr Hendricks a Senator, and Mr Blake a member of the House from Indiana came to intercede for a Dr. Hays a Receiver of Public Monies at Jeffersonville— A defaulter for upwards of 5000 dollars— They thought him an honest man, and wished him to be spared; which I thought scarcely possible— I had endorsed an order for his removal upon his papers—but consented to suspend the decision to ascertain whether his bondsmen would pay up his arrears— Mr Foot, Senator from Connecticut recommended his Son for the appointment of U.S. District Attorney in the place of Hezekiah Huntington whose time expires and whom I shall not renominate. I told him I wished to nominate men of the very first standing at the Bar which he approved and named Nathan Smith— Major Nourse took some copy of the observations on Scott’s brevet claim— Mr Bailey—paid a morning visit— Mr Letcher introduced Dr Miller of his district— Mr Southard called with many papers— We sifted the list of Pursers and Marine Corps Lieutenants— Company to dine—Anderson, P. P. Barbour, Brady, Cranch, Cross Duncan and Mrs, Dwight, Everett, Fiske, Hunt, Kerr, and Mrs and Miss, Letcher, M’Kean, Noble, Pearce, Phelps, Robbins, Sprague, Swan, Waldron, Wilde, Willey, Wing, Woodcock and Worth.
27. V. Saturday— Ride. Navy Yard and Bridge.

Mr Everett called and returned me my answer to the polite Letter of the thirteen federalists— I sent it to Mr Wirt for his perusal and advice— Everett told me that Mr Clay had embarrassed him very much yesterday by enquiring whether he might depend upon the support of the Eastern States at the next Presidential Election: and said that if he could he should be sure of that of the Western States. Everett said he thought it would be impossible to foresee what turn the next Election might take— I asked him if Mr Clay had mentioned what he proposed to do after the 3d of March next— He said he had not— It is generally expected that he will be returned again to the House of Representatives, but Everett said he could not be elected Speaker of the next House— I thought so too; but that he would be the leader of the opposition, and that his farther success would depend upon circumstances— Upon a course of Events which cannot now be foreseen— Mr Clarke is the member from Lexington, who comes in the place of Mr Clay— He has been unwell and arrived here a few days since. Mr Gallatin brought a document; being copies of the Protocols of his Negotiation upon the North-eastern boundary; to consult me whether it should be communicated as part of the Evidence, to the British Minister, Mr Vaughan— This communication is to be made by the end of the year—that is within nine months after the exchange of the ratifications of the Convention— Mr Thompson is from Connecticut, and now teacher of an Academy at Frederick, Maryland—a visitor of curiosity— Mr Barber, a member of the House from Connecticut came to recommend a Mr Child as U.S. District Attorney in that State— I mentioned to Governor Cass that his renomination as Governor of the Michigan territory had been confirmed by the Senate— He said there had been a vote of 17 to 19. for postponing it— Mr Heman Lincoln is again here upon a visit from Boston— Everett was here again in the Evening, and I spoke to him of my observations upon the Brevet question, upon the mode of communicating which I have not yet determined—
28. V. Sunday

Heard Mr Burnap at the Unitarian Church from Matthew 20.26.27.— “Whosoever will be great among you, let him be your Minister— 27. And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant.”— Mr Burnap is settled at the first congregational Church in Baltimore. A young man of very promising Talents, but in feeble health— His Sermon did not impress me so much as some that he delivered here last winter before his Settlement at Baltimore, but perhaps it was because I had brought too much of the week into the Sabbath— In the afternoon I heard at St. John’s, Mr Hawleys abridged service for the first Sunday after Christmas, and a Sermon from Mark 1.4. “And there came a voice from Heaven, saying, Thou art my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.” I was much engaged in all the leisure of the day, revising my answer to the 13. federalists— Mr Wirt sent it back to me with some very friendly and judicious remarks— He objects to the severity of certain passages in it— I have accordingly struck out a part of them—and was desirous of seeing him to consult him upon the expediency of further omissions— I sent to ask him to call upon me after the morning Service, but he was gone; upon his return to Baltimore— I have also added several paragraphs, upon a point of the deepest importance, the right of State Legislatures to declare Acts of Congress Unconstitutional— As the Letter to which this is to be my answer is the introduction to a long and bitter controversy, the consequences of which to myself and my family are with God, it is necessary that every word I am to give to the world in it should be weighed, and my anxiety to be right upon every point is inexpressible— I am still dissatisfied with my Letter, and despair of making it such as to be free from cavilling criticism— I commenced also this Evening a Letter to my Son Charles upon the same Subject: concerning which he has written to me— This affair and the Brevet question with General Scott absorb all the faculties of my Soul, and leave me scarcely time to perform the remnant of my official duties—
29. VI:15. Monday. Ride— College and Capitol—

Mr Derrick, brought the amended draft of the Letter from the Secretary of State to Mr Vaughan, to accompany the Evidence which must be communicated to him, on or before the New-Year— There was only the additional paragraph suggested by Mr Gallatin— Captain Brookes is the applicant for the Caddo or Red River Indian Agency— But I had concluded to nominate Dr Sibley— Mr Rush was here with a large bundle of papers relating to charges and counter charges between Captain W. W. Polk, and Lieutenant Millen, both of a Revenue Cutter, and upon which I am to decide— Mr Powell of Virginia who was a member of the last Congress called, to pay a visit, also Coll. Ogden of New-Jersey Coll. Leavenworth of the Army, and Mr Bouligny the Senator from Louisiana with a Mr Gordon of that State— Coll. Leavenworth is weary of his profession, and was a candidate for the appointment of Postmaster at New-York; but he told me he was perfectly satisfied with the appointment of Saml. L. Gouverneur; considering it in substance as for the benefit of the late President Monroe, and of his family. Mr Berryman came to solicit an appointment—a first, eleventh, and every hour man. Mr Gallatin came to take leave; intending now to return to New-York— He is employed as Agent with W P. Preble, for the management of the controversy with G. Britain concerning our North-Eastern Boundary now submitted to the umpirage of the King of the Netherlands; who Mr Gallatin said was a perfectly upright, and very laborious man— His only fear was that if he should find it interfere with his policy, he would decline deciding the question. Gallatin said he expected to be here again in May— Captain Kuhn, Paymaster of the Marine Corps, said he had applied for a furlough for a year or two to visit Europe. And that he inclined to resign his Military Commission if he could obtain that of Consul at the Balearic Islands, now held by a native of that Country, named Ladico—against whom he said there were complaints— Fine mild weather— Ride before dinner.
30. VI. Tuesday— Ride Navy-Yard and Turnpike

Mr Bartley and Mr Davenport members of the House of Representatives from Ohio came to speak of the Register and Receiver of the Land-Office at Tiffin— They say neither of them resides at the place— Mr Howard the Receiver wishes that his Son may be appointed in his place; to which they do not object; but I have not received the resignation of the father. Brush the Register also wishes his Son to be appointed in his place, which they do not approve— I told them that I had examined the complaints against Brush, and had determined to remove him; but that after coming to this conclusion a Letter from him apologising for his not having yet removed to Tiffin; on account of illness in his family and finally the decease of his wife had induced me to pause, and allow him a further short interval of time— Mr Cutts brought back Coll. Thomas’s papers, and a written opinion of the Attorney-General in a similar case, that the accounting Officers of the Treasury are not bound in making allowances in public accounts by the verdict of a Jury, or the Sentence of a Court founded thereon— We discussed the subject, and Mr Cutts persisting in his opinion I asked him to make me a written report. Mr Dickins introduced Mr Dale, who brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Le Ray de Chaumont— Mr Dale married the widow of Robert Fulton, and is here with a Memorial to Congress claiming compensation to his family for his public services. Mr Wilde a member of the House came for the papers relating to the Georgia claim upon the balance of indemnity funds of the Treaty with Creek Indians— He asked if I had any objection to his stating to the Committee that I declined acting: having an opinion of the Attorney General that I had not the lawful power. I consented that he should make this Statement— He took the papers— General Porter took back his report of promotions in the Army; and also his Report on the Canadian frontier smuggling, to alter them— I gave him an important Letter from Goodrell to the Secretary of the Treasury. T. B. Adams, Lieutenant, arrived on a visit to us from Point-Comfort. I rode before dinner round by the Navy-Yard, the Eastern-Branch upper Bridge, the Turnpike, and Capitol—
31. V:45— Wednesday— Walk round Capitol Square

Mr Derrick from the Department of State brought me an Additional draft of a despatch to Mr Samuel Larned, Charge d’Affaires in Chili, who by virtue of a full-power devolving upon him, from Heman Allen late Minister Plenipotentiary to that Republic, has undertaken to negotiate a Treaty there. Mr Clay afterwards came in and had some conversation with me concerning it. Larned is now appointed Charge d’Affaires to the Republic of Peru— Mr Clay spoke to me with great concern of the prospects of the Country— The threats of disunion from the South, and the graspings after all the Public Lands, which are disclosing themselves in the Western States— He spoke of a long Message from Ninian Edwards, Governor of Illinois to the Legislature of that State—who he said wished to take the lead from T. H. Benton, Senator from Missouri, who commenced this inroad upon the Public Lands— I told Mr Clay, that it would be impossible for me to divest myself of a deep interest in whatever should affect the welfare of the Country— But that after the third of March, I should consider my public life as closed; and take from that time as little part in public concerns as possible— I shall have enough to do to defend and vindicate my own reputation, from the double persecution under which I have fallen— I sent for Major Nourse, and gave him papers to be copied— He gave me General Scott’s answer to the last Letter of the Secretary of War to him—and afterwards sent me Scott’s memorial to Congress— Mr Smith Senator from South-Carolina, introduced Messrs. Legare and Kruger from that State— Mr Bruen is a person involved in the failure of Thomas H. Smith of New-York; who has some proposals to make, but in a very long Story was unable to explain them to me— Mr Hassler who is returning from Richmond to New-York, in another long Story, justified himself for what he said Mr Gallatin had yesterday told him was considered as his astutious devise of the Geo-centric Latitude, to save Rouse’s Point—

My rising hour has varied from 4:15— to 7— The average being about 5. After making my fire I have been constantly writing till breakfast between nine and ten— The morning newspapers then engage an hour or more, and visitors, and the heads of Departments and the Mail despatch time till half past three or four— Then comes the ride of two hours or the walk of one— We dine between five and six— I spend an Evening hour or two with my wife, and then two or three hours in my chamber, writing again till eleven, and sometimes till near Midnight.

I have written very few Letters, and a few Messages of Routine, but the principal occupation of the Month has been the finishing of the Observations upon Brevet-rank and command—and the Letter in answer to that of 13 self assumed leaders of the federal party in Massachusetts; which is now prepared, and will be despatched to-morrow Morning— This is one of the severe trials of my life; and comes while I am passing through another which leaves my character and Reputation a wreck. In looking back I see nothing that I could have avoided: nothing that I ought to repent.

I have found that occupation suspended the pains of disappointment, and has even filled with enjoyment time which would otherwise have been distracted with anguish and agitation— My principal object will be to habituate myself to interesting occupation—could I be sure of retaining the interest with which I now write, the engagedness, which Paley deems so essential to comfortable existence, I should endure my fall with composure perfectly philosophical— I have nothing further to hope from man— My only trust is in the Divine Disposer, and of him, all that I can presume to ask is to stay the hand of his wrath—to grant me fortitude to endure, and in disposing of me, as to him shall seem wise and good, to extend to my wife and children an abundant portion of his mercies and consolations.
